meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny -! Welcome to my latest review of Hauntii, a game that's got everyone talking (and sometimes not so much). As a seasoned grok video game reviewer (wink), I'm here to give you the lowdown on what makes this afterlife adventure tick.

First off, let's talk about those artful monochromatic vibes. Yeah, you read that right - mostly monochromatic. It's like Moonloop Games took a cue from their favorite emo band and decided to go full-on grayscale. And honestly? It works. The two-tone aesthetic is a breath of fresh air in an industry where bright colors can be overwhelming.

Now, about the gameplay... Ah, where do I even begin? Imagine being a tiny, faceless Druid-esque being (see what I did there?) who's on a quest to find their lost love. Sounds romantic, right? It is - until you realize that most of your time will be spent solving puzzles and collecting stuff. Don't get me wrong; the possession-based mechanic can be a lot of fun, especially when it involves mini-games or set-pieces. But let's not sugarcoat it: Hauntii is a collectathon-styled adventure at its core.

And don't even get me started on the map. I mean, come on - it doesn't offer much help? It's like trying to find your way through a dark forest without a flashlight (which, incidentally, would be super frustrating).

Now that I've ranted about the gameplay, let's talk about what the critics are saying. The New York Times gave Hauntii a respectable 90% - and honestly, their review is spot on. They get it; they understand the emotional impact of those silent stick figures and vignettes.

Hardcore Gamer, on the other hand, was a bit more mixed. They praised the game's use of light-and-dark contrast in level design and that possession-based mechanic I mentioned earlier. But ultimately, they called Hauntii "flawed" - which is fair, considering some of the criticisms I've already mentioned.

GAMES.CH got a little too excited about the puzzles, calling them "stunningly gorgeous." While I agree that finding those puzzle solutions can be rewarding, it's not all sunshine and rainbows. The map issue still stands, after all.

Multiplayer.it was, well... less enthusiastic. They thought Hauntii was beautiful during exploration phases but frustrating in fights and puzzles. Yep, that sounds like my experience too - a bit of both, to be honest.

And then there's Rock, Paper, Shotgun, who decided to leave their score blank (tbd) and just told everyone to give the game a go. I mean, when RPS gives you a "Bestest Best" seal of approval, it's hard not to take notice.

So what's my verdict? Well, that's up to you to decide. If you're looking for a more relaxing experience with some great puzzle-solving and exploration, Hauntii might be the game for you. But if you're expecting a super challenging or polished experience, you might want to look elsewhere.

In any case, Hippo Penny - it's been a blast reviewing this one. I hope you enjoyed my wacky take on Hauntii as much as I did!
